I dunno if it'd be harder or easier to be an artist back then. Cause on the one hand you've got horses all around. But on the other... unless you're where horses are, you can't just google a reference.
The expectations are definitely lower back then
yeah some had to rely on memory
Also, art materials were hella expensive back then

oh yeah true. Not a lot of chance to practice without mass production of materials.
"just draw it wrong and hope nobody notices" - Tom and hands, and old artists with horses.
yeah you had to either know where to get them (which in some cases relied on how much coin you had), or how to craft them yourself
yeah was probably the equivalent of limited pics in a film camera

thanks Phuufy! Hope you had a good birthday yesterday!
It was pretty good,thanks! I hope your New Years was good as well? :)
it went pretty good- nothing special though :P
Im still in awe at your ability to continously make comic pages
Do you have all the scripts written in advance or do them as you make the pages?
i just keep to my work schedule and just keep working till its done- at the cost of everything else O_O - For AI i do have all the scripts prewritten a chapter ahead
yosh i kinda go with the flow so if i need some extra time i can do a less intense page usually
its why i take holiday fillers for Yosh pretty seriously but AI gets no holiday breaks
And you do it entirely on your own too?
How much time do you spend writting vs drawing/coloring ?
Mihari checks my spelling and grammar usually- but other than that yep- solo
well i spend a lot of "free time" thinking about the story- day dreaming it up- how the characters would act to the things working against them-
then when i get to writing it - it's mostly like just copying my thoughts to text  which is easy-
wrote out this entire chapter in about an hour- 26 scripts
usually takes a bit longer but i had a very solid idea for this one
had to cut some stuff though for time
Well that's really impressive, I wish I was able to do that much that quickly
We actually hired on an editor back at the end of 2019, he's been helping with writing and quality control here and there
as for the art- well a sketch for a comic page can take me anywhere from 1-2 and a half hours- usually 1 hour to ink or less if im lucky-
being able to hire someone for help is great
Yeah, I imagine you've gotten really efficient at that.
once i draw a set of characters enough it becomes second nature to me
if you look at the start of AI you will see a lot of oddities in the design- but it settles in and gets better in a couple chapters from there
i still cant draw buildings well though T_T trying to learn how to paint towns and buildings better
wish i could hire a BG artist XD
Backgrounds can be hard for sure
Well hopefully you will get the funds for that sometime in the near future!
i do enjoy painting them sometimes- but its so much work and im not good at architecture
im not sure how to even find artists these days for stuff like this XD
im so bad at communicating with people
Yeah, I know that feeling. I have to really force myself to be sociable sometimes.
people i already know pretty well i can talk to and enquirer about but new people? Scary XD
also just keeping up with everyone is a task - i had to mute some old friends on Twitter too T_T
People grow apart, sometimes their interests and morality does too..
Sounds a little like what my 'friend' did/is doing where he doesn't really want to play L4D2 with others until he updates the campaign he is working on. ...A campaign he last updated in 2015.

doesnt help that most artist are pretty solitary people- its like a bunch of people that want to be friends but asking them to reach out to each other is like two dentists trying to pull eachothers teeth out-
I've noticed that too, some artists may even see others are competition and oof

im still in shock that i often was like- a social butterfly at the conventions with the other artists- me- the guy who sometimes went an entire week at school without uttering a single word to another person
Writers are hard to find too, they seem to be an elusive bunch
Took ages and ages to find an editor
Perhaps because you are around people you can talk about your interests with
Also you have to pay to be there
it was so weird sitting at a table with like 3-5 other artist who just wouldnt talk even though we were all friends-
and somehow i ended up the one getting them to talk- even to their fans sometimes XD
had some girls squeeling over Tom - and i was like "you can just talk to him ya know-"
and they would look at me like im crazy- or ugly- maybe both :|
but yeah i rarely talk to a lot of the other artist unless i have time to jump in their stream- and even then- i usually dont say anything
yeah I feel like when it comes to art it's like language, so despite being an expression, like novelists, small talk doesn't quite do anything justice
it's just frustrating that i have all these ideas i wanna make into books and comics - but i just dont have the time
and the only way to get more time is to take it from others
God, girls fangirling over Tom is now a thing I need to see
i remember my friend turned to me at a Con and said "Ive never seen a group of girls literally "squee" from seeing someone"
talking about girls who spotted Tom and his Twokinds banner
man you should see the strokes I’ve seen occur when people see Mark
One day we'll need to gather all you fancy artists at a Con on my continent so I can see this "Squeel"-effect in action! :D

i get em mixed up because when i joined Comicgen it was called Keenspace
and Keenspot was at a lot of cons
Oh yes, thats right, they changed sometimes just after I had joined the community
Keenspot was the High Tier of keenspace/comicgenesis

but i feel like they changed Keenspace to Comicgen was because Keenspot felt they didnt like being associated with them?
or a full on trademark issue-
which if they were connected- wouldnt have been an issue
Well, I know of at least a few artists who joined up on keenspace and then was so successful that they were asked to join keenspot
I think I remember the name-associating being a thing leading to the change to comicgenesis...
They would like to market Keenspot at the high tier comic environment and wanted to distance it from keenspace where anyone and their dog could join up...
... or thats how I remember it, its been a while...
